subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Schwa/wedge merger in QS
msgSnippet: There is an international English pronunciation that could be used or simply the pronunciation used in Androcles and the Lion.  If you do not want to pay
messageBody:
There is an international English pronunciation that could be used or simply the pronunciation used in Androcles and the Lion.  If you do not want to pay attention to this idea then simply label your QS as Canadian, Cockney, etc., assuming the other person can pick it up.  Frankly, I think it is hard enough to read QS as it is without complicating it with the variability in the English vowels.  This is probably why Read's alphabet is more of a novelty than as a practical way to write English. 

--- On Fri, 11/13/09, Warren <warren_janssens@...> wrote:

From: Warren <warren_janssens@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Schwa/wedge merger in QS
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Friday, November 13, 2009, 2:17 PM

 
I believe they should have been retained for those that hear and speak these differently. I believe that he removed them over a concern that most people could not spontaneously produce the correct spelling -- but I don't thing that is a valid concern. As long as the rules make sense, you'll remember the canonical spelling if you are exposed to it enough times. If you don't hear or speak the differences then it's fine to change the spellings for your own use.

I think a more important question is how do you determine whose local canonical spelling becomes the international standard. Or would you have different dictionaries for Canada, US, UK, Australia, and Jamaica? As a western Canadian I don't hear or speak the difference between the two and I merge other sounds as well in daily speech. I don't think it would be a problem for people to learn the canonical spellings of words even though they don't hear or speak them that way.

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, "Charles Smith" <Roasted_Beanie@ ...> wrote:
>
> I've been wondering about this for a while, and I want everyone's
> opinion. What do you think of the fact that schwa /@/ and wedge /V/
> share a letter in QS? Do you agree or disagree with this merger?
> Shavian had separate letters for these sounds, which is the way I think
> it should be. (Also, as a consequence of this merger in QS, the sounds
> 3` and @` [as well as @r, as in "array"] share the same sequence.) Has
> anyone thought to propose an extra letter to make the distinction?
> Perhaps one could separate the two versions of #36 to make the
> distinction.
>
> This isn't to say, however, that I don't like QS, because I do; I've
> been using it since the early 2000s (on and off admittedly). If QS were
> ever to be considered to replace the Latin alphabet, I'd be
> wholeheartedly in favor of it. This is just one of the few issues I
> have with QS.
>
